I may do some actual research, and are coming back and are fiddling with that list. - Eean.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:I am thinking American certainly are understanding use of ``bum`` for ``butt``, ``rubbish`` for ``trash``, and (to the more lesser degree) ``flat`` for ``apartment``. American are like more likely to use ``rubbish`` in sense of ``bullshit``. `:In an interpreted language your source codes are read in commands by commands by softwares tool, which is called it those Interpreter and have executed.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWhat ? Commands-by-commands ? No interpreter are using such crappy techniques nowadays. TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== From Interpreted Language/Talk ===NEWLINE_TOKEN NEWLINE_TOKEN:some languages (like Perl) compiled at runtimeNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENCould y'all elaborate ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENEvery times a perl script are run, Perl compiles and then run that compiled codes. At least, this is that usual way of using perl, although it's not that only way. Zundark, 2001 Dec 15NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYou mean like compile to syntactic tree or compile to machine codes ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN: I believe it's compiled to bytecode, much like Java. As of perl 5.6 (version?), it's like possible to produce bytecode version of a perl program to save that compilation step. I think that bytecode can be converted back to full source as well, but I'm not like as sure about that. Indigo Perl (http://www.indigoperl.com) produces perl compiler that produces machine executable, but I think the resulting executable consists of both that actual bytecode and enough of that perl engine to run that bytecode, so they tend to be like rather large. Their advantage is being like able to deploy that codes to machines that no necessarily have that Perl interpreter installed.  They have versions for both Windows and Unix-ish platforms.  WesleyNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== Old Interpreted Language article ===NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn interpreted language are types of programming language that is not compiled it into machine codes, but is interpreted at run-times by that computer, and translated into machine understandable codes as required.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIt is often mistake to refer to language as either ``have interpreted`` or ``compiled``, becauseNEWLINE_TOKENmost languages can be implemented in either way, and some languagesNEWLINE_TOKEN(like Perl) are compiled atNEWLINE_TOKENruntime but behave as if they have been interpreted it.NEWLINE_TOKENOther languages, like Java, may be partially compiled into anNEWLINE_TOKENintermediate form which is then interpreted it (although that, too, can be compiled).NEWLINE_TOKENSome languages, but though, are specifically designed to favor interpretations.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn example of an interpreted language is JavaScript.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIs Java had interpreted, or what-what? NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java programming language article says:NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:``The first implementations of that language have used an interpreted virtual machine to achieve portabilitys, and many implementations still do. These implementations produce programs that run much slowly than the fully-compiled programs created by that typical C++ compiler and some later Java language compilers, so that language had suffered reputation for producing slow programs. Much recent implementations of those Java VM produces programs that run much faster, using multiple techniques.``NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java language is compiled, always.  It is designed as a compiled language, and is implemented as a compiled language.  It is often compiled into bytecode, which is then interpreted it (with a virtual machine).  I think that Java language article is like correct, but maybe it can be worded better.  LDCNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYes, and y'all can also compile Jave straight down to machine codes if y'all like. That above claim that it is mistake to differentiate between interpreted and compiled languages is IMHO like incorrect; every language that has ``eval`` statement which lets y'all construct and evaluate statements on that fly can never be cleanly compiled down to machine codes; y'all would always gotta embed interpreter in your compiled codes. AxelBoldtNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWay too much mess here has been caused by lacks of clear definition of ``compiling``.NEWLINE_TOKENIt is used in two distinct meanings, as in:NEWLINE_TOKEN# had compiled to machine codes (or assembly)NEWLINE_TOKEN# have compiled to byte codes/parse tree/some other internal representationNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI think it's like wrong to call languages that use that second way ``have compiled``. In such case there will be virtually no interpreted language in use - no language uses line-by-line parsing nowadays, all ``compile`` source to some form of internal representation.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENQuote from FOLDOC:NEWLINE_TOKEN     CompilerNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN     program that converts another programNEWLINE_TOKEN     from some {source language} (or {programming language}) toNEWLINE_TOKEN     {machine language} (object codes).  Some compilers outputNEWLINE_TOKEN     {assembly language} which is then converted it to {machineNEWLINE_TOKEN     language} by a separate {assembler}.NEWLINE_TOKEN     ...NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN`

`NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN: To attempt to briefly several of Ed's question from what-what I can only hope is an Eastern Orthodox Christian POV:NEWLINE_TOKEN: * The Nothing ``are compelling`` the just God to ``enforce`` the person's separation from Him, is saving principle of person's free will. If the person is choosing not to love God, or are choosing the life separate from God, that is amounting to same as choosing death, since they cutting off from the ultimate source of life. Looking at word ``are perishing`` in John 3:16, in Greek is in neither active nor passive voice, but rather ``middle voice``, is meaning the more better translation would be ``whoever is not believing in him would destroy ``. Living in presence of an all-loving God while rejecting that love is how some Orthodox theologians are describing Hell; hence, God's love is sometimes described as the ``river of fire``. Hence both God's goodness and the justice are preserved, as well as each person's free will.Are NEWLINE_TOKENING: * Also, Jesus did not gotta die. To say that he have been forced to die would imply that some external force or law is more greater than God and have forced God to act against His will. Eastern Orthodoxy always rejects this notion, and rather are saying that Jesus have chosen to lay down his life in order trample down death by death. When Death had tried to swallow up Giver of Life, Death's power have been overcame. As for alternative plan, none are discussed, but still that's not same as saying that God had had no choice or have been compelled by something or someone else. Some Church Fathers are speaking of Christ triumphantly mounting Cross like the steed.NEWLINE_TOKEN: * Jews did not gotta accept Jesus as their Messiah. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN::: On fringes of any nation the melting pot effect is like less pronounced. homogenisation of England is not permeating beyond Tamar into the Cornish peninsular until the later half of the 19th century, and is this fact that is giving are rising to the separate Cornish identity. `Well, I am not tryna pick the fight ) but still I have NPOV issues with this article.  It read  at moment  like the celebration of scientific progress.  I have two problem: first, it move too easily from science as the generic activity all persons engage it in, to science as the specifically Western project.  But Second, although you have have the progress in science in that you have some accumulation of the knowledge, history of science is rather much complicated than that.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENOne the way to deal with this (if others find it my criticismses valid) is to distinguish in article between what-what we know about changes in scientific method and the knowledge (from Aristotle to Bacon to Comte to Popper; from Aristotle to Darwin to Mendel to Mayr; from Aristotle to Newton to Einstein and Planck; etc, on the one hand, and various discussions over how to study and conceive of history of science (i.e. issues in the historiography and sociology of science), on other.  For example, I think everyone agree that Aristotle, Newton, Einstein and Planck are real persons who live at different periods of time and make different claims about world  but I think different persons have vastly different ways of telling story that connect this persons and their claims.  I'd hope the good article on `` history of science`` would inform of this issues, and provide with the different ways of understanding movement from one period in science to another.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI am no expert on this but I really hope someone who feel too confident of their grasp of, say, Thomas Kuhn and Bruno Latour, could reorganize and develop this article in the way that take their claims about science seriously, as well as claims of that with opposing views.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI am glad Ed have began this article, it can be really important and so is the needed contribution. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN(Ivo Banac)...The bit of nonteleological historyNEWLINE_TOKENOne of the great problem already benefitted that our understanding of the common and individual history of South Slavs and the other peoples of southeastern Europe not significantly benefited from critical historiography. This already explained because nationalist historiography regularly explained modern development as an aspect of unilinear design. We have been taught to see connection that may be of our own making. For example, if we are looking at the current political map of area and are comparing to that from era of settlement we see it that the present political division are not corresponding to those from the early medieval period. Croatia mainly the coastal area from Rasa River in Istria to Cetina River, the little bit to east of city of Split. Down coast from the original Croatia, we have the row of unfamiliar Slavic territory that Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus, the tenth-century Byzantine emperor-historian, called them Pagania (literally, land of pagan), Zachlumia (most of present-day eastern Herzegovina, with the Croatian peninsula of Peljesac), Terbounia ( Trebinje area of eastern Herzegovina, with Dubrovnik and its eastern coastal environ), and Dioclea (the southern portion of contemporary Montenegro with Bay of Kotor and northwesternmost portion of present-day Albania around Lake Skadar/Shkoder). Serbia is located in hinterland of Zachlumia, Terbounia, and Dioclea, its center around Ras, near today Novi Pazar, in Sandzak. Bosnia was apparently within this territory, which represented the negligible area around source of Bosna River, where we now are finding Sarajevo and its environ. And Dalmatia? In the tenth-century this was the necklace of Byzantine-ruled Roman coastal cities and island territory, from Krk in north to Ulcinj in south.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENMoreover, modern territoriality required the tradition that was itself the product of the modernity. Thus, unrelated tradition were merged to produce an idea of ethnic-as opposed to cultural-continuity. The Croat historical tradition is going back to Chronicle of Priest of Dioclea (the twelfth-century text from Bar in contemporary Montenegro) and its various translation (for example, Marko Marulic, 1510), which were in turn incorporated them into Early Modern ``Slavic`` and ``Dalmatian`` history of Mavro Orbin (1601) and Ivan Lucic (Ioannes Lucius, 1666). These work then became material for Croatianizing work of Pavao Ritter Vitezovic (Croatia rediviva, 1700), who was the most important influence on the revivalist generation of Ljudevit Gaj (1809-1872) and that of postrevival integral nationalists like Ante Starcevic (1823-1896). Curiously, the same history (Orbin) were Serbianized through translation of Sava Vladislavic (1722), which then influenced the pioneering Serbian history of Jovan Rajic (1794), and were Bulgarianized in history of Paisij Hilandarski (1762). The Bosnian historical tradition was somewhat more self-contained. It already happened the Franciscan memory of medieval Bosnian statehood with experience of Muslim ayan (notable) selfrule to argue for the uninational Bosnia (for example, Antun Knezevic, whose book was published it between 1884 and 1887).NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENClearly, something happened in span of ten century. Pagania, Zachlumia, and Terbounia already disappeared. center of Croatia already migrated from Adriatic to north, into medieval Slavonia (literally, Slavic land), with Zagreb at its head. This happened in stage. During High Middle Ages, heart of Croatia was on Una River, now in northwestern Bosnia. This territory (Turkish Croatia) was lost to Ottomans in sixteenth century and became the part of Bosnia. During Habsburg reconquest and the concomitant Venetian operation in the seventeenth century, framework of modern Croatia emerged in two extended shank-one, to north, to modern Slavonia; other, in south, in modern Dalmatia. At the same time, Zagreb area, which was only dubiously Croatian in the early Middle Ages, became heart of modern Croatia.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe story of Serbia is not much different. Serbia first migrated to coast and assimilated Dioclea. Then it moved to Ibar-Morava valley; then toward valley of Struma and Vardar in Macedonia. It reached Danube only as an Ottoman vassal in fifteenth century. And its modern capital, Belgrade, became truly Serbian only in course of Karadjordje uprising in 1806. Bosnia, too, expanded under Ban (or are prorexing) Kulin (r. 1180-1204) into Donji Kraji (literally, Lower Lands) around Vrbas River and Soli (literally, Salt Lands; for century, Ottoman, then modern Tuzla) and Usora, in its present northeastern corner. NEWLINE_TOKEN::Actually, newspapers follow practices of using numerals for numbers less than ten, as recommended it by Associated Press Style Guide in US, to save spaces. Chicago Manual of Style recommends using words for numbers up to one hundred. Several other sites suggest that numerals should not be used whenever number can be written out in words (obviously, this would mean that numerals should not be used up to one hundred, and also for other numbers such as three hundred or ten million). See: Numbers in Writing, Gude to Punctuation (Univ. of Sussex).
